description: From elector (“person eligible to vote in an election; German prince entitled to elect the emperor of the Holy Roman Empire”) +‎ -ate (suffix denoting an office or rank; or something characterized by [the specified word]). Elector is ultimately derived from Proto-Indo-European *leǵ- (“to collect, gather”).

entries.meaning: The collective people of a country, state, or electoral district who are entitled to vote.
examples: The votes have been counted and the electorate has spoken.

entries.meaning: (historical) The office, or area of dominion, of an Elector (“a German prince entitled to elect the emperor of the Holy Roman Empire”); an electorship.
(chiefly Australia, New Zealand) A geographical area represented by one or more elected officials; a constituency, an electoral district.
examples: The electorate of Finchley borders on the electorate of Much-Binding-in-the-Marsh, splitting the new housing estate of Royal Cupolas.
